utterances: Exactly.
What are some other interesting uses of discarded materials to make this work?

As engineers, we'll spend a lot of time thinking about how we affix antennas to different locations, some of the funny ways that people have figured out how to affix these antennas - 'cause you want them to be as high as possible is to take rectangular oil cans and lash them sideways, using this weird, cantilever rope-knot system that I've never seen before.
You don't expect to see these jerry cans just sticking out of things like telephone poles or power poles, or just the sides of fences.
And then this weird-looking antenna.
It's made out of plywood and chicken wire and it often has plastic bags wrapped around it.
But the weird thing is, you get high-speed Internet off of the stuff.
Now, if I understand this, somebody has satellite Internet connection into Jalalabad.
In effect, all of this is extending access to that to everybody else around the city, fair enough?
Yeah.
We have a fab lab in a suburb of Jalalabad, and we since moved it to the center of Jalalabad.

We had this really high-speed Internet connection and people said, we want to do some kind of project where we also have the benefit of all of these capabilities but spread out in the places where we actually live and work and actually hang out.
Do you find that at the various fab labs that MIT has established around the world, that people in very different places share their solutions and find them applicable?
Or are the conditions really quite unique to one place, as opposed to another, and not so transferable?
Now, that's one of the coolest, most super-exciting things about the fab lab, is most everything that everyone wants to do comes down to just a few basic ideas.
We're going on eight years of having fab labs all around the world.
And despite having not the same language and all different kinds of technical and knowledge backgrounds, we're really able to share and build on projects that everyone else has done.
Well, Amy Sun, thank you very much for talking with us about it.
My pleasure.
That's Amy Sun, a research assistant and doctoral candidate at MIT's Center for Bits and Atoms.
Welcome back to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
If you heard the program last weekend, you'll know we were in Los Angeles, and one afternoon, we stopped into one of Jonathan Gold's favorite restaurants to have lunch.
Gold is the food critic at the alternative newspaper, The L.A.
Weekly, and three years ago, he became the first food writer in history to win a Pulitzer Prize for criticism.
He eats almost everything, like guacamole topped with fried crickets.
I never realized that fried crickets were so freaking good.
He loves hot and sour soup with sea cucumber.
You sort of have to wrap your mind around that there are, like, slithery pieces of invertebrate floating around in it.
There's pretty much just one thing Jonathan Gold doesn't like: eggs -boiled, fried, doesn't matter.
It must be a childhood thing.
My earliest conscious memory is of, you know, looking up at my mom when I was two-and-a-half years old and saying, you know, I have just eaten my last plate of scrambled eggs.
When we met Jonathan Gold for lunch at El Parian on West Pico Boulevard in Los Angeles, he was hard to miss with his long, reddish hair.
Gold's been described as a man who wouldn't look at a place on a pirate ship.
This restaurant serves Mexican food, Jalisco-style.
And from the front, the place looks shuttered, abandoned, but inside, it's teeming with life.
I'll have an order of the birria.
Okay.
And he'll have one too.
And
Birria is the signature dish here.
It's roast goat swimming in a savory, vinegary broth of trippings(ph) flavored with chili and cloves.
There's like crisp parts and there's chewy parts and there're soft parts.
It's really delicious.
It's a chemical compound called myoglobin.
And there's nothing scary about it.
There's nothing dangerous about it.
All it is is myoglobin.
It's a chemical compound that helps oxygen reach muscles.
And if you think about a chicken, it spends most of its life on its legs.
And also, those legs are working and moving, and so those muscles will have a lot of myoglobin, and that's why the meat is dark.

Whereas a breast on a chicken, because a chicken doesn't fly, those breasts aren't being moved very much and they sort of relax, and so there's a lack of myoglobin, hence why the meat is pretty fair in color.
Now, is dark meat really that much fatter?
Well, you know, I mean, there is a little bit more fat, but it really is marginal.
And I think there's this well-publicized claim that breast meat is much healthier for you, and I really think to some degree that's erroneous.
You know, when you have skinless, well-trimmed dark meat, it's incredibly healthful.
And when you look at data that's published by the USDA on their own website...
That's the U.S.
Department of Agriculture.
Exactly.
When it comes to citing calories, there's actually very little to distinguish between skinless chicken breasts and skinless thighs.
The breasts have 114 calories, and the thighs have 119, which basically means that if you did a couple of sit-ups, you'd burn off those extra calories.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And again, in terms of fat, there really isn't much difference in it.
And when it comes to nutrients, personally, I think dark meat really wins hands-down.
It has higher levels of iron.
It has higher levels of zinc, thiamine, riboflavin and Vitamin B.
So you're really getting a good nutritional boost with dark meat.
I assume that dark meat is your personal preference because you're giving it a good rep here.
It is.
I hope I didn't make that too obvious.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I'm Malaysian myself, and so I really grew up on dark meat.
And in our house, when we were young, we would always fight for the chicken legs, and the breast would always sit there looking sad and paltry.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Now, if we have perhaps convinced some people to try a little bit of dark meat next time, do you have a favorite recipe?
I do.
Personally, you know, I love to stir-fry with dark chicken meat, these boneless, skinless chicken thighs.
And it's really no different than cooking with boneless, skinless chicken breasts.
You know, you just - you cut it up into bite-size pieces.
But the real advantage is that it really stays really nice and moist.
So what I do is I just cut it up into bite-size pieces.
I'll season it with some soy sauce, some ginger, some crushed garlic, a bit of sesame oil, maybe, and then stir-fry that up with, you know, lots of fresh vegetables.
And it's so quick.
And I think it's very user friendly and very accessible, and it's a great starting point for someone who wants to start cooking with dark meat.
Check out our website, npr.org, for a copy of Nadia Arumugam's recipe.
Nadia Arumugam is a food writer.
She's based in New York City.
Thank you very much for talking to us today.
Thank you, Linda.
It was great to talk to you.
